As I said before, Australia is very poorly served at the moment, not by the government but by the so-called opposition. What the honourable member for Gwydir should be doing is getting behind Senator Collins in his lobbying on the US farm bill, and not getting up here attacking legislation which has the purpose of assisting in Australia's exports and the value adding of Australian agricultural products.

PARA.TAB: Before I finish, it is important for me to go back and talk about my electorate. There are great opportunities for export from Far North Queensland of Far North Queensland products. As people know, in the 1980s Cairns airport became the nation's first locally controlled international airport. Alongside the Cairns seaport, this provides an excellent infrastructure for the supply of goods. Freeport, Indonesia, is already being supplied by Cairns. Our position as part of the western Pacific and South-East Asia offers huge opportunities for Far North Queensland.

It is very interesting to look at the record of the potential for air cargo from Cairns. The volume of air cargo passing through Cairns airport has shown a spectacular growth in recent years. International air cargo has doubled every year from 1989-90 to 1992-93, reaching 14.8 million kilograms in 1992-93. International air cargo, which overtook domestic cargo in volume in 1991-92, has benefited from the opening up of new freight routes, particularly into the Asian markets, as the number of passenger services has increased.

The flow-on impact of increased air cargo space to far northern producers has been enormous, and has spurred the development of a plethora of new export industries in the far north. That is what this legislation provides potential for. That is what this legislation is about, and that is what the shadow spokesman failed to mention in his speech. He failed to talk about it. All he talked about was doom and gloom, and he talked down the Australian economy. The opposition knows there is an election coming up so it has to talk down the Australian economy. It cannot give any credit to the government in terms of the minister representing Australian farmers overseas or in terms of this legislation which the industry welcomes and which I commend to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —As seconder of the amendment moved by the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) to this legislation, I take the opportunity to rise and speak in support of the comments made by the member for Gwydir which, in spite of the unfortunate attack upon him by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), were really hitting the spot. I might say, too, that I will acknowledge the justice of one comment from the member for Leichhardt, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) is in Washington. If that is where he is, and I accept what the member for Leichhardt says, it is very important indeed that Australia's interests should be presented to the American congress as this is 1995 and the year of their farm bill.

PARA.TAB: As members will know, the American farm bill only comes up for reassessment or amendment every five years. The last one was 1990. This year, 1995, is one that is going to be of great significance to Australia. I know that because, in spite of the negative remarks by the member for Leichhardt about the National Party, as a member of the National Party I was in Washington in April lobbying from the Vice-President down for the Australian primary producers. I take great pride in the fact that I was able to be there with a parliamentary delegation led by Senator Michael Beahan. It was an all-party delegation which attacked this in a bipartisan fashion, and that is the way it should be. I was privileged to be in the delegation. Because I was a National Party member and very conversant with things rural, I was able to be the major spokesman and the focus of the representations being made to the Americans on the needs of Australian primary producers.

It is particularly important to realise that the American farm bill is American domestic policy. This is one of the things that I and other members of the delegation said on every opportunity. We said to people—and I actually said this to Vice-President Gore—`We realise this is your domestic policy. It is none of our business, except that you have to realise that if you cough, we get influenza.' That is true. We were also very concerned about the impact of what the Americans have done with their export enhancement program, EEP.

The most senior person we spoke with was the Vice-President, which is almost as high as you can get. After that we met Pat Roberts, who was the chairman of the House agriculture committee. Senator Richard Lugar was very involved in his preparations for announcing his candidacy for the presidency, and we were not able to see him, but we also had very useful talks with other officials in Washington such as the Library of Congress research people involved in the formulation of the policy.

Australia's primary producers should be aware that there is not going to be an easy answer to this. There are basically two farm bills coming through. One is from the Senate, sponsored by Senator Lugar, and he is making a much stronger move and seeking to have the subsidies reduced significantly. The one coming through from the House takes a much softer approach, and is more concerned with maintaining the subsidies.

Everywhere that we went throughout the United States on the rest of the delegation, we told people that we had been talking in Washington about this on behalf of Australia's primary producers, and all the Americans said, `What's going to happen?' Nobody knows. The reality will probably be that the subsidies will be reduced to some extent. We should realise that it is not just EEP. There is a whole range of ways American primary producers are subsidised—like the food stamps program, which is bound up with welfare as well—so it is very important that we understand what is happening there.

The reality is that the Americans do have to reduce their deficit. Theirs is on the same scale as the deficit of this government. Let us, while we are at it, realise that that deficit is not a surplus of $700-odd million. What a confection! What a farce! What fairy floss from the show! The real deficit is at least $8 billion. The New South Wales farmers have recently published a journal which quotes from Bain and Co. and shows that the real, fair dinkum deficit is probably over $12 billion. That is going to impact severely on Australia's primary producers.

While I have the floor, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to make a point about the primary producers in my electorate of Cowper. I note what the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) and the member for Leichhardt have been saying about their particular areas. The north coast of New South Wales is the major cattle breeding area for the whole of New South Wales. In fact, 70 per cent of the cattle bred in New South Wales are bred on the north coast. It is a particularly important industry for the north coast of New South Wales. We have major saleyards at Kempsey which handle a lot of cattle. Again, at Macksville there are excellent saleyards, and the major abattoir that we have is Midco at Macksville. I have to give full praise to the management and workers of Midco. They do a tremendous job, and produce great exports for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good to see someone giving credit to the workers.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The member for Leichhardt persists with sanctimonious interventions. I ask that he desist. The member for Cowper has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that the meatworks at Macksville used to be a cooperative. Unfortunately, they fell upon hard times some years ago. When I was first elected in 1984 they were in a situation where a receiver had been appointed. They were in great trouble, so much so that one of the first things I did on being elected to this parliament was to have the Parliamentary Library prepare a special research paper on the economic impact on the Nambucca Valley, should that meatworks close. That is how close it was.

PARA.TAB: I know there are differing views about importing capital, and particularly about the impact of Japanese investment in Australia. But I must say that, since the Midco meatworks at Macksville was purchased by the Japanese firm Mitsubishi, that meatworks has gone from strength to strength. It has had its ups and downs but, by and large, it has been the iron lung of the Nambucca Valley and also, of course, beyond. People from places such as Stuarts Point and Bellingen actually work there. There are hundreds of employees. Over the last 10 years, I do not know how many millions of dollars Mitsubishi has invested, but it has made major investments, sometimes of $20 million in one whack. To go through that works and see the men at work is a great pleasure. The equipment and the lines are state of the art: all stainless steel. The efficiency of those fellows, as you see them working on the beast, is a joy to behold. They are really great people. The primary producers are well served by that abattoir. There is also another small one, the Everson one at Frederickton in the McLeay Valley, which also does a very good job, though on a much smaller scale.

In conclusion, the meat industry and the primary producers of Australia are of vital importance. Whilst some people tend to denigrate the value of primary production, it is still the mainstay of Australia's exports: one should have no doubt about that. I take this opportunity—to use the favourite phrase of my leader, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fischer)—to salute the primary producers, the workers and the meat processors of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand as part of the question. I call the honourable member for Capricornia. I understand her confusion, and I presume that it suits her participate in the debate at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, when I heard your predecessor in the chair suddenly begin to speak very slowly, I knew that something was up, so I thought I had better high-tail here to the Main Committee. Of course, when I heard the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) speaking—my good comrade, as I referred to him yesterday, and a good agrarian socialist, indeed—I thought that I had better get here. I will definitely be delighted to contribute to the debate on the second reading of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: I noted, as I was rushing here, that my colleague the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) did draw attention to the shadow spokesperson's contribution in the Main Committee yesterday. Indeed, I was physically in attendance and listened without any interjection to his speech, irrespective of the fact that he referred to me in less than helpful terms. Any review of the transcript of Hansard in the debates in which I have followed the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) would indicate that I have acknowledged his commitment not only to his constituency but also to the industry. I certainly have not put out press releases as he has done: misrepresenting, in this case, me, as member for Capricornia, and based on a complete misunderstanding or mischievous analysis of what I said in the House. Had I had his press release at the time, I would have referred to him specifically in my explanation to the House a few weeks ago.

But I will pass over that matter, because the member for Gwydir, the opposition spokesperson, did raise some criticisms of this bill. Firstly, he criticised the fact that it was actually being debated in this chamber, a criticism which I thought was irrelevant. He indicated that the opposition would, in general, support this bill with a second reading amendment. We should remind ourselves that the Cattle Council of Australia and all the peak bodies involved in the meat industry in this country are supporting this legislation and these recommendations.

The member for Gwydir criticised the lack in the bill of any procedures to implement the Industry Commission report. From the report, he quoted the first couple of paragraphs of the overview. Indeed, he quoted from the very first paragraph. We have to be very careful of selective quoting; and, while I do not deny that what the member quoted was exactly what the report says, let me read from the end of the overview about the effects of the Industry Commission's recommendations. In part, the conclusions of the overview read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission's recommendations build on reforms which have been initiated over the last decade. They have been made with a view to facilitating the transition from a commodity based, adversarial industry with low levels of skills towards a modern, collaborative and productive industry.
In particular, they are designed to:

increase the level of skill in the workplace, the flexibility with which it is deployed and the level of workplace health and safety; assist the process of achieving greater market access for Australian meat and meat products; increase commercial incentives for firms to conduct their own research, development and market promotion . . .

That is, they have been designed to take government off the back of the industry. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has indicated that he wants to take government off the backs of the people. In this bill, the government has provided for the industry to take control of its destiny, to take control of its own procedures and to make itself more competitive and outward looking. Yet all we get is carping criticism from the opposition and a pretty fair wallop of union bashing from the opposition spokesperson, the member for Gwydir, yesterday. But I digress from the effects of the recommendations of the Industry Commission, which continue:
. . . increase the extent to which the industry, whether on its own or in collaboration with government, is able to adopt a means of ensuring the hygiene and safety of its output at least cost—
obviously a key issue for exporters—

increase the capacity of producers and processors to receive feedback on how they can each meet each other's needs; reduce the level of direct public sector involvement in the industry; and facilitate measures to reduce costs and increase productivity in all sectors of the industry.
These are commendable recommendations. The matters in the bill, involving the restructuring of the industry, are designed to produce those results.

PARA.TAB: The other issue that we have to be very careful about is to make sure that all parties in the industry are involved, including producers. For too long, there has been a tendency, particularly among members of the opposition, to say, `It is the meat processors, in particular the meat workers, who cause all the problems.' The member for Gwydir referred to the Booz Allen and Hamilton report for the Cattle Council of Australia, International comparisons in the beef processing industry, which is an excellent document. His aim in referring to this was to show how uncompetitive the Australian beef industry is.

One of the important points made on page 35 of this review is that up to 70 per cent of the processing gap—defined in the report as $198.49 a head—is beyond the control of processors, but that around 30 per cent is addressable. It is very important to know this. All sectors of the industry, particularly the processing end, are willing to address that issue. The report does make international comparisons, but it is misleading for the member for Gwydir to mention figures from industries in countries such as Argentina and America, when the report itself clearly makes the point that only 30 per cent of this is to do with the processing industry. This is hardly the point made by the opposition spokesperson and comes from a report initiated by the Cattle Council of Australia.

The other report that the member for Gwydir used was the report made by Fellows Medlock and Associates, dated March 1995. This was a report to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) entitled Review of progress in workplace reform in the export meat processing sector. I am delighted that the opposition spokesperson referred to this, but once again he quoted rather selectively to suggest that all the problems in the meat processing industry were the fault of the unions. I believe that this is unhelpful to the debate and I will refer to aspects of the report to clarify the position. It will be instructive to all members. Under the heading `Difficulties or impediments to enterprise bargaining' the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a number of evident impediments to enterprise bargaining are dealt with throughout the report and are summarised below. The major impediment lies in the attitudes of the industry's employers, union officials and employees. Whilst employers and unions have expressed positive views about the need to change, this has to a large extent not been reflected in action. That this has not occurred illustrates the poor relationships which exist in the industry with trust and goodwill clearly lacking. Where co-operative relationships have been established, it is possible to point to progress in improving productivity at plant level.

The key issue for this industry is making a difference to that cost gap of 30 per cent, but it will require changes to the culture of the workplace: changes in the attitudes of management, of unions and of the work force, and not only at the national level but also on a plant-by-plant basis. There is evidence that, where the culture of the workplace is an issue and there is a need to educate and train employees and take them through the process, you can actually achieve very positive results.

PARA.TAB: The other issue that I think is important is this: what are the impediments to change? This is referred to on page 5 of the report. Impediments to change identified by this report included the following:

SPEECH.PARA: a) Employers: with some exceptions, the industry's individual employers generally display a traditional and narrow approach to relations with their employees and unions and have failed to acknowledge change where it has occurred. The concept of Best Practice is not well understood by the industry's employers who have generally looked for excuses rather than accept that the initiative for reform must lie with management.

And the report is critical of the union and the work force. In the industry, there is a clear lack of unity and common purpose among all participants. Failure to support the central role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the absence of a respected and visionary employer association are major impediments to reform.

PARA.TAB: I make these points to indicate that there have been initiatives on all sides, from the processing end, from the producer end and from the government end. Indeed, our reforms have reflected that change. However, we are talking about a very conservative industry on both sides, an industry where there has been a tendency to use very out-of-date industrial relations mechanisms on both sides but where there is a preparedness and a willingness to change. However, that has to be capitalised on. The conclusions in the overview state:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the on-going debate about the relative significance of workplace reform in the overall competitiveness of the industry, there is a broad agreement among the various parties that reform will improve performance at an individual and company level. However, before sustained improvements can be achieved, it is essential that a clear, consistent and supportive message is delivered at the workplace by both employers and unions. From the views expressed during the course of this review, it is evident that sufficient commonality exists for the parties to develop a shared agenda as the basis of a commitment to a widespread education process about the need for, and benefits of, workplace reform. The challenge for all the parties involved will be to translate their support for reform into a concrete action plan for change at the individual company level.

That is the challenge for this industry and the one that all of us should be supporting. Having gone through a very effective consultation process with all players in the industry, the Industry Commission, on page 29 of its report, concludes:

All parties expressed scepticism about any ability to achieve reform at the industry level. There is no body, at this stage, which has sufficient respect or support to be able to play a role in bringing the parties together to foster reform. While reform must be focused at the individual plant level, an industry-wide vision for change, supported by agreed principles and a broad action plan could play an essential role in educating the parties and facilitating enterprise level reform.

It is certainly the case that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is one party to that reform but, if management and unions think that is the only way to do this, we will not achieve a great deal. The unions have shown a preparedness to be very flexible but, at the same time, that must be based on some degree of trust and confidence so that, where agreements are developed, employers will follow through on their promises. There is no doubt that educating the workplace, which is as much a challenge to the unions as it is to the employers, is going to be very important in this process.

PARA.TAB: I want to give a classic example of this issue in my electorate of Rockhampton, where Australia Meat Holdings is at present in dispute with the AMIEU. I have had discussions with some representatives of AMH. I have discussed with them the sorts of initiatives the company has put into its operation at Guyra, which I dare say the opposition spokesperson must know about because it is in his electorate. He did not mention it yesterday. I think that at one level AMH is keen to adopt productive processes whereby it can initiate the sort of changes that are needed to improve capital utilisation. I have not had a chance to talk to the employees as Guyra but I know the union has some concerns about the way the process was developed. In the Country Life of 1 June, the AMH chairman, Keith Lawson, is reported as follows:

"Enterprise bargaining does offer the industry real hope. It will have significant ramifications and it is important that producers understand that reform has been resisted and is therefore slow," Mr Lawson said.
"But we are committed to getting it right. It is our only hope of survival against international competitors."

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that at the bottom end of this kind of process we have got a situation at AMH Fitzroy Abattoirs, in my electorate, where the employees, having gone through a long process of trying to develop an enterprise agreement and working under an industrial award from the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission, became so frustrated that they walked off the job one Friday afternoon. They did not follow the disputes resolution procedure technically, but they were prepared to come back on the Monday and to re-initiate the process if they could get some commitment from AMH to follow through on the promises that had been made. What followed was essentially a lock-out of the work force, with public pronouncements by the industrial relations spokesperson to the effect that the company was simply going to re-hire anybody who would come—precipitating a strikebreaking operation.

PARA.TAB: The union, in attempting to get a resolution according to the agreed-upon disputes resolution, spent considerable time attempting to get some agreement with the AMH representative and in the end had to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission. That will be heard tomorrow in Brisbane. At the same time, I understand, AMH was in the Industrial Relations Commission because it is in conflict with MATFA over whether or not it should be a signatory to the industry-wide award.

While I understand the frustration and concern of AMH, the way it has gone about attempting to resolve this dispute will not forward an effective, productive enterprise bargaining agreement. The work force believes that the management will re-employ a number of the workers but pick off the workers that it does not want. The resolution yesterday at the picket line was that all workers would re-apply for their jobs but the union expected all its members to be re-employed, so that the enterprise negotiation would go ahead. In fact, the union officials obtained a commitment from the work force that workers would not stage any sort of walkout unless it was sanctioned by a state official. The union officials in this situation have worked very hard to forward the process of enterprise bargaining, but feel a great lack of confidence in the position of management.

It is this kind of industrial dispute that, in my view, will put back enterprise bargaining for years in Rockhampton. It is an industry that is absolutely essential to the economy of Rockhampton. We have had the Smorgons Lakes Creek meatworks closed all year, because Smorgons decided to divest itself of its entire company structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who could blame them?

—I am asked who could blame them, but I am talking not simply about the company's meat processing industry but the whole thing. In the meantime, the company did not give two hoots about what happened to the workers and their families in Rockhampton. It held out and held out in terms of paying the redundancy payments that were due to those workers—workers who have to suffer seasonal working arrangements and hiring and firing on a daily basis. Basically, people in this place should know that we are talking about an industry that goes back a long way. It is a piece of industrial archaeology, to quote the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is not conducive to getting good performance out of any employee.
—Who could blame them.

—I think if any member here worked inside this industry, they would perhaps take a different view of how it should be done. At the end of the day I urge, and I have done so, the people from AMH to sit down and start negotiating a way through this mess. They need to provide education and skill formation, and they need to do something constructive about bringing their work force with them. AMH may well decide that it can just pull the pin and move its operations but that will not help the beef producers of Central Queensland. At the moment, because our two meatworks are closed, our cattle producers are having to freight their stock to Brisbane. The cost involved in that is huge. I was at a meeting at Claremont where the AMH representative was having a crack at workers by saying, `It's all the fault of the work force.' The producers were saying, `Yes, that is true.' But, at the end of the day, the meat processing companies screw down not only their work force but also the beef producers: cattlemen and women work hard to put up prime beef for sale only to get the lowest price possible.

PARA.TAB: There is a great need, at all levels of this industry, for men and women of goodwill to sit down and work out how best they can forward this industry which is so vital to Australia's future. I urge all players in this industry to do that, including the opposition. I would like to know the opposition's policy on this issue. All we hear from the opposition is criticism, in spite of the support of all of the peak bodies to this legislation. The government is once again delivering on reform. It is about getting the government off the back of the industry and about asking the industry to take responsibility for its processes, to become competitive, to get niche markets and to make sure of the product that it is producing. One of our problems is that we do not grain feed a lot of our beef. We still use open range and that makes us less competitive. There are a number of issues involved here. It is not just the poor old meatworker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to convey my appreciation to the House for the circumstances we found ourselves in a few moments ago and convey my apologies to you.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—I think your appreciation should be directed to the former Deputy Speaker, who was most accommodating at that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the House's attention not so much to the industry problems that other members have outlined but to the exotic animal disease aspect of this legislation. It has concerned me for some time that there is a change in the ethos in assessing the vulnerability of Australia to the imported exotic diseases. It may be a fairly roundabout process but I ask the House to bear with me as we trace the change in the processes used by the government, and the animal quarantine and export branch of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service. I think we can find part of the answer there that we need to have if we are going to build a safe and secure animal production industry in Australia. Safe and secure animal production for Australia is critical. Not only must we have an input into research and development, and the latest techniques of production, but we must be safeguarding our great industries as well.

PARA.TAB: I wish to take the House back to the notorious case of the import of pig meat, take that as a case example, look at poultry production and draw from that some conclusions as to what might be proper practices and policies for this nation in the future. As far back as 1988, there were circulars from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with regard to pig reproduction centres and pig import conditions. Those circulars laid out some of the criteria that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy sought to impose upon those people producing pig meat in international circumstances and the conditions of quarantine that would apply should Australia consider the import of pig meat.

At that time, there was great activity in the pig and poultry industries, as growers and producers tried to assess what, for them, was an innovation—the idea that Australia should actually be an importer of these fragile primary products, which notoriously could present a risk for Australian producers should exotic diseases gain entry into Australia in any way.
At that time, I wrote to the then minister for resources, the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), asking him for details. He responded in August 1991. In that letter, he said:

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is a transparent and accountable organisation that uses the best advice available when assessing proposals and developing protocols for the importation of animals and their products into Australia. The procedure followed varies in the detail depending on the perceived risks and similarity of the proposal to pre-existing protocols. There are however some basic steps which are common to all major policy decisions such as producing new importation policies. These are characterised by extensive consultation with scientific and industrial bodies eg the state and Northern Territory agriculture departments or equivalent, the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA), the CSIRO and the National Farmers Federation (NFF). Specialist national industry groups such as the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and the Australian Poultry Industry Association, are also approached when their industry is involved. Overseas experts and organisations are also frequently consulted on specialised topics and the Veterinary Services of the exporting countries provide information on animal health in those countries. The AQIS Bulletin, a monthly publication available through the Australian Government Publishing Service, carries notices of AQIS's reviews and solicits comments.
Through this consultative mechanism, AQIS obtains the best scientific information on which to base its decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a good letter, and it outlines, pretty fairly, the way in which Australia should look at these matters.

PARA.TAB: There is another factor that I will raise later. It is the need for Australia to preserve its unique position, in intensely competitive markets, of having disease free, clean food products. That is something that is a priceless comparative advantage to us in any market. It is something that we need to preserve, because too many would want to see us destroy our comparative advantage of clean products and would want to see extra costs loaded onto Australian producers if we should import disease.

The former minister's letter, of 21 August 1991, seems a reasonable letter. I decided, at that time, to test the minister's response and take up with the international expert bodies exactly what AQIS had done in order to consult widely. I had already consulted the Australian Veterinary Association, the CSIRO and the NFF. I had spoken to and received documentation from the Australian Pig Industry Council and the Australian Poultry Industry Association. The only group that I was unfamiliar with and did not have information from was the group of overseas experts that AQIS had consulted in giving advice to the government on whether or not Australia should import pig meat.

I wrote to the universities and national institutions the names of which the minister supplied as having been consulted. I was somewhat surprised by the responses I received. Let me read some of the names of those authorities which were consulted by AQIS as being world authorities which could provide advice on which a scientific decision as to whether or not Australia should import pig meat could be based. The list reads: Agriculture Canada, Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Australian Veterinary Association, Bureau of Rural Resources, Cambridge University, Chief Quarantine Officers (Animals) in all states and NT, Counsellor (Veterinary Services) Brussels, Iowa State University, Malaysian Veterinary Research Institute, New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Singapore Department of Primary Production, State Veterinary Institute for Virus Research, Denmark, United Kingdom Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, United States Department of Agriculture, University of Melbourne, University of Queensland and Veterinary Counsellor, Washington.

I wrote to those groups and I would like now to read some of the responses to the House, because I believe that what we have before us is misleading, if not fraudulent, behaviour on the part of AQIS, in the way in which it spoke to the minister and provided advice to the minister. I will read first of all a letter from the British High Commissioner. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Cadman,

In his letter to you of 2 August the High Commissioner (who is currently travelling with a visiting British Minister) said that we would be asking our Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food if they could provide copies or details of any submissions made by them or by Cambridge University to the inquiry conducted by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) into the import of Canadian pigmeat.

The Ministry have now replied saying that they have no trace of any such submissions. I understand that it is quite possible that any contribution which they may have made to the AQIS inquiry would have been provided as answers to specific questions put to them by AQIS, rather than in the form of a written submission.
A very nice informal approach on such a serious issue, I would have thought, and one completely unacceptable in such important decision taking. The letter continues:

The officials concerned would not necessarily have known that the questions were being asked in relation to an inquiry into Canadian pigmeat. I am sorry to say, therefore, that on the face of it we are unable to meet your request. But if you are able to provide any more detailed information about the dates on which consultations took place, preferably with the names of officials involved, I should be happy to make further inquiries.

I could not do that, but the British High Commission had full details of the statements by the minister and what the minister said. I had a response from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, from the Bureau of Rural Resources, which gave me some breakdown on costs and charges on an economic basis, from the pig meat people of Australia, from the New Zealand government and from the government of the United States. I would have to say that in every instance of my contact with overseas experts, the response was similar to that of the British High Commission. If contact had been made, it was not known by the Australian representatives on their inquiries with universities, or with specialist groups.

PARA.TAB: It is of deep concern to me that, based on what appears to be false and misleading information, we as a nation made a decision based on a very cooperative attitude from the Canadian government, which had a wonderful relationship with the Australian department and the minister and which said, `There is no risk whatsoever of our pig meat bringing in disease to Australia, and here are the authorities and bodies that we wish to quote.' I would say that is prejudiced advice and, if the Australian government makes decisions in this way, I think that we are in a dangerous situation.

We have before us the proposition that Australia should import chicken meat from Thailand, Denmark and the United States. I have to use this opportunity to raise my deep concern that this not become another process of the type that we saw undertaken by the Australian government or its advisers in regard to pig meat. Fortunately, there have not been any grave consequences of the pig meat importation, though there may have been one outbreak of mystery swine disease created by the import of that Canadian pig meat—nobody has been able to say yes or no. Are we going to face the prospect of our poultry industry and then our beef industry and other industries being treated in this same way? The minister's letters are very revealing, because the basis of the decision used by AQIS and the government is not on a no-risk policy but on what is an acceptable risk, so there is an endeavour to evaluate the cost of importing an exotic disease and the economic loss against the gain.

In the chicken meat industry, the economic gain to consumers is said to be about $3 million a year. The cost to the industry if there were an outbreak of Newcastle disease is estimated, on average, at about $30 million a year. So if we get one outbreak in a 10-year period, any economic advantage is lost immediately.
In examining the AQIS position, I turned to AQIS's pamphlet on Newcastle disease, which is the disease most likely to threaten the Australian poultry industry. The pamphlet says:

SPEECH.PARA: Newcastle disease, the most feared avian disease in the world has penetrated into most countries. Australia so far is free from the pathogenic forms of this disease.
When the disease first enters a country it can cause havoc in the bird industry—commercial flocks, fancy birds, pet birds and native wild birds are all susceptible.
Thousands of birds may die. Those that appear to recover can pass the disease on to healthy birds and may themselves remain chronically ill for the rest of their lives.
There is no known cure for Newcastle Disease. The disease is caused by a virus so drugs do not help. Birds continue dying even if heavily medicated.
That is from an AQIS pamphlet on Newcastle disease.

PARA.TAB: I sought some expert information. Dr Balkar Bains—who is one of the most widely respected authorities on poultry disease in the world—states that the possibility of introducing Newcastle disease through imports of cooked meat is real, that the spread of the disease could not be controlled and that it could decimate the native bird population of Australia. He says, `The evidence is not speculative, it is real.'

I know and admire Dr Paul Gilchrist, as a person who has contributed mightily to the Australian poultry industry and to knowledge on avian diseases, and would be the most widely recognised authority on poultry diseases in New South Wales. He has recently written papers called `Newcastle disease is a threat to native birds' and `Further comment—response to the AQIS position'. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Researches (1985) reported 100% cent mortality in Eastern Rosellas within six (6) days of artificial exposure to Newcastle Disease.'
He also says:

Researches (1989) tested 1,235 Australian birds of 130 species for Newcastle Disease virus and antibodies and none gave a positive response. This tends to confirm the lack of exposure of and thus probable susceptibility of our native birds.

That is from Dr Paul Gilchrist. If we set the poultry industry to one side and go to the scientific evidence, we can see that AQIS has been derelict in chasing hard scientific evidence. We have two eminent world authorities, both Australians, saying there is a real risk to Australian native bird life here, and we have AQIS continuing to pursue the line with the minister—and with the Australian parliament—that there is an acceptable risk to bringing poultry meat into Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have to raise serious doubts about whether or not we are pursuing a proper course here. I would like to see a full inquiry as to the advice provided by AQIS and the thoroughness of its investigations in all of these matters. I would like to see a detailed analysis of how AQIS arrives at what is an `acceptable risk', because it seems to me that a 10 to one bet on whether or not there is going to be an outbreak is not an acceptable risk. I would like to see it be more like a 100 to one risk factor if we were even going to contemplate this process.

Let me return to what I think is the nub of the whole situation, which is Australia's comparative advantage over the rest of the world. We have, at close quarters, some very active and highly productive countries. We live in a fiercely competitive world, in terms of agricultural products. If we are not going to defend the comparative advantage we have with clean food products, then we ought to pack up the Australian primary industries right now, because it is a philosophy that one cannot apply to one industry and not to another. It is no good for the beef growers of Australia to say that we could do without some elements of the poultry industry.

The way the argument runs, an acceptable risk is if there is a small economic advantage. I have illustrated the small economic advantage to the consumers of Australia. With $3 million a year spread over hundreds of millions of pieces of poultry consumed by Australians in a year, the advantage for the individual consumer is infinitesimal. If you said to the average Aussie, `I would like you to pay 25c more a bird to make sure that we do not import disease, and our guarantee is that we are not going to let Newcastle disease into the Australian parrot population,' the kids of Australia would rise up in their schools and say, `We will pay 25c to make sure that Australia remains disease free.'

This is not a protectionist issue. The degree to which this argument on protection has gone on based on animal diseases is stupid, because we are running a risk of denying ourselves the comparative advantage that we have in an intensely competitive world trade in animal and agricultural products. Unless we stay with some semblance of being disease free and can sell without fear or favour around the world Australian products which are known to be disease free, then we will become like the rest of the world and, despite the economies of production, the tyranny of distance will kill our producers.

I raise this in what I know is basically a beef debate. But I do so because I am really concerned about the direction I see the protection of Australian animals, flocks and vegetable products going. Our crops are also facing the same sort of threat. I will wait with great interest to hear from the minister the assertions and support that he cannot give in his correspondence, because he does say in the last few lines of his correspondence that there is no guarantee. He says that AQIS cannot give a guarantee that Australian flocks would be free of Newcastle disease. I think this is a terrible decision. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address my remarks mainly to the meat industry and I would like to raise the simple question: how are these new proposals being put forward by the government really going to tackle the central problems facing the meat industry today? This is what ought to be concerning all honourable members and it seems to me that it is the one area that the government seems to have skirted around. In fact, one would have to say that we could judge them as being a failure.

PARA.TAB: We do not have to go any further than the Industry Commission report on meat processing released in July last year, which was quite a while ago when you think about it. The government has had all this time to address some of the core problems. Instead of doing that, we are now going off onto another tangent, changing a lot of the structures around the meat industry but, at the same time, avoiding the primary problem. In the overview of the Industry Commission report, which has a very informative way of putting the problems in perspective, it says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia produces livestock at very low cost by international standards. However, efficient processing is necessary if we are to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production.
Although Australian meat is generally price competitive on export markets, this is largely because processors are able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with processors in other countries.
I think that puts it in a very stark perspective. The report goes on to say:

This inquiry has found that, despite some recent improvements, Australia's meat processing industry operates at significantly higher cost than processing industries of most countries with which it competes. It has also found that Australian meat exports have been losing market share in almost all our major export markets.

I would suggest to all honourable members that there are two very strong messages there. One is the fact that our processing costs are higher than those of our competitors, which is only compensated for by the fact that livestock producers are being paid less. The other more chilling fact is that we are losing market share in almost all our major export markets. I would have thought that the alarm bells would be going off. I find it most disconcerting to listen to some of the government members who seem to be completely avoiding this point and are not able to come to grips with it.

PARA.TAB: What is even more galling about this is to listen to the comments that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made which were reported by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), in his address. He said that, when asked a question about the problems of the high processing costs, the Prime Minister said, `Aren't you a mug for highlighting the inefficiency of the Australian beef producer.' The Prime Minister obviously completely misunderstood the industry; he had no idea. I would have thought that that same description could be applied to many of the contributions by government members to this debate.

Before I leave the Industry Commission report, I want to look very closely at the point that was made in the overview which seems to have escaped government members completely. They come in here like robots and suggest that members of the coalition are just knocking the workers and all they want to do is get lower wages. Talk about ignorant! They obviously have not even read the report. If we look at page 16 of the overview, we will find some comments about the industrial relations problems which really are the core issue in this whole question of trying to get a more efficient meat processing industry. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The industry has been disadvantaged by a poor industrial relations climate and a poor occupational health and safety record.

Remember, we are talking about an industry that has had this problem for many years, but, equally, we are talking about a government that has been in power for 12 years and has done mighty little to address the problem. The report continues:

Features of the industry's award system inhibit innovation and have contributed to industrial unrest. Seniority systems and daily hire provide insufficient incentives for training and skills development. The complexity of the tally system, and its structure of premium rates of remuneration for extra output, reduces incentives for improving working conditions and productivity.
Capacity utilisation of the Australian industry is lower than that of our competitors, resulting in higher fixed costs per unit of output.
Further on, it says:
The Commission has found—
this is the important point—
that greater flexibility—particularly greater use of enterprise agreements—could bring about significant productivity gains, with benefits—
I emphasise this point—
for workers, producers, processors and some consumers.

Obviously, the government members were unable to get this far into the report to see that what is being proposed by the Industry Commission—the core issue—is actually going to be for the benefit of the workers, not to their disadvantage, as people like the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) tried to claim when they came in and made their contributions.

PARA.TAB: It seems extraordinary that it has taken report after report to highlight what has been so obvious to so many in the industry who have understood what has been going on for some years. Australia is the net loser because of the government's failure to act.

We now have a package of bills which does not address that core issue but does a number of other things such as increase the minister's power over the structures to run the industry. It fails to address some of the major problems with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, as my colleague the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was discussing in his contribution, and it still does not address the primary problem of how we make the meat industry more competitive on an international scale. I guess that, as usual, the government wants to be seen to be doing something, rather than getting in and tackling the central points. If we look at one of the claims in these bills themselves, apart from the fact those opposite do not address some of these core issues, there is a claim that there is no cost in introducing these changes to the AMLC.

As I think anyone would know, if significant changes are made to the structures that are operating, it is likely to cause quite a lot of dislocation and there will be some costs, not only directly but indirectly, as people try to adjust to those changes. Clearly, they will have some difficulty in focusing on some of the core issues as they make those adjustments. If we take the question of market information, there is no explanation there as to whether or not the quality or, indeed, the quantity of market information is going to be improved by this change.

A second point is about the question of a minister increasing his power in the whole issue. He has now been given two very key powers: he can veto or, indeed, vary the corporate plans of the Meat Industry Council, the Meat and Livestock Corporation or the Meat Research Corporation. So that is very significant power—a power not only to veto but also to vary. He can have a very big degree of influence and involvement through the guidelines, approvals and appointments of key people on the boards of the various bodies. This is fraught with danger. There is a very real risk that, if a minister wanted to abuse that position, he could do enormous danger to this industry by appointing his cronies or people who are not competent to do the job to the best of their ability.

I flag this concern because I think it is something that the government ought to be held accountable for. Clearly, by vesting so much power in a minister, there is a very real risk that the industry could suffer. We only have to look at the last two ministers for primary industry to see some of the shortcomings that I am referring to. When it comes to the meat industry, we have had a choice between two ministers—the current minister who seems to know nothing about the industry, and the previous minister who really did nothing. That is the choice we have had with this current government: the know-nothing or the do-nothing.

I now come to my third point, which concerns the whole question of AQIS, the Quarantine and Inspection Service. Again, if we look at the Industry Commission's report, we find that it suggests that AQIS should be split into two. We clearly need more competitiveness in the whole question of meat inspection. I do not think it is good enough to continue to have a complete monopoly, as AQIS currently has. I think it is worth also reminding honourable members that meat inspection is a most expensive—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.44 a.m. to 12.06 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, one of the areas that does require some attention, as the Industry Commission report has pointed out, is the whole question of inspection services. Meat inspection in Australia costs producers around $90 million a year. That is not an insignificant sum, especially when you look at what some of our competitors pay. For example, in the United States, they pay nothing; meat inspection is provided by the government. One of the other points that is long overdue for recognition is the need to change our inspection system. As I said, this should involve not only splitting AQIS into two, but also looking at a system similar to the HACCP, the hazard analysis critical control point system, on the whole of meat inspection. One of the concerns is that, at the moment, we basically rely on end-point inspection which really only allows a quick glance at the appearance of the meat and clearly could easily overlook some of the possible problems that the whole inspection service is designed to avoid.

PARA.TAB: Today's consumers require more than just a visual inspection. They want the microbiological tests. They want to make sure that the product is clean and that problems that are undetectable to the eye have, in fact, been avoided. Clearly, if we are going to do that, all stages of the processing chain, from the time of transport and from production itself, have to be looked at and what we might call a quality assurance system has to be instituted. This would not only guarantee a safer product but would also, I think, guarantee a better product. That is the whole point of this HACCP system because it eliminates this risk. Therefore I think it is time that we started to look at this, instead of the government continuing with the existing system which clearly has some shortcomings. This would dovetail very nicely into some of the work that the Cattle Council has been doing in developing its quality assurance program.

The fourth point, and probably the most significant one, is the whole question of industrial relations. As has been shown in the Industry Commission report—and was, in fact, shown in the Booz Allen and Hamilton report a couple of years ago—we do have a major problem in the cost of processing in Australia. That is why we are in the alarming position where not only are Australian processing costs much higher and Australian producers are receiving less than their counterparts in other countries but, at the same time, we are losing market share in many of our export markets. Part of the industrial relations problem that has been highlighted also adds to the fact that our processing costs are, in many cases, double that of the New Zealanders and more than twice what it costs to process in the United States.

We can look at other parts of the chain, for example, the whole waterfront system. We have seen $430 million spent there, half of it provided by taxpayers, yet if we look at the latest Contship assessment, the performance of Australian ports is slipping back down the list. So all that money has been spent only to see that our performance is deteriorating when it is compared with that of other ports around the world.

I have highlighted the industrial relations problem as it affects the meat industry in the processing area. I have mentioned the problems in the waterfront. We could also look at some of the inefficiencies in transport. But I come back to the point I made that was highlighted in the Industry Commission report: it is not a question, as some of the honourable members opposite have tried to portray it, of trying to force workers into poorer conditions or lower wages. It is quite the opposite. It is by increasing the productivity and by getting greater efficiency that, in fact, everyone can benefit.

It is a tragedy for this industry and the country that Australian meat processors and producers have to pay a very high price for a system which all commentators in this country have recognised is inefficient. Only the Labor Party seems unable to realise that we are putting a major impediment in the way of improving our export performance in this industry and, indeed, in just about every other industry.

Producers are the ones who are suffering. It has been estimated that the average cattle producer in Australia is getting from $50 to $100 per head less than they would be getting if Australia had a world competitive system for processing and transporting products. This was illustrated very clearly by a recent example when Queensland, ostensibly because of the drought problem, found itself in a position where it had to import beef from United States and New Zealand. After paying all the costs of shipping that meat to Australia—and cattle producers in the United States are paid far more than the Australian producers—the beef could still be landed in Queensland at a competitive price compared with the Australian product. More clearly than anything else, that illustrates what a dreadful problem we have and, as I see it, the legislation does virtually nothing to address it. It is a forerunner to some of the other problems that the industry is going to face if we do not get efficiency into the whole process. Already it is clear that parts of South America are going to be able to send their meat into the United States and we will find that that will be very competitive.

I would like to point out one issue which I think the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) has made a lot of noise about, that is, the importance of getting women involved in some of these associated boards. Everyone would agree with the thrust of that, but, when he talks about having quotas, it raises some concerns. Looking at government appointments to date, it is very hard to find people other than men. The most recent appointment, which only reinforces this point, has been to the position of chairman of the Meat and Livestock Corporation. It was none other than the former minister for primary industry, Mr Kerin. The government representative on the Meat Industry Council is a man, the government representative on the ILC is a man, and the Meat Research Council is headed up by a man. Most of these people are very competent, but I do not think the government's record is followed up by its rhetoric.

In conclusion, I would like to raise these concerns again because one of our major primary industries is being sorely hampered by the fact that the government has failed to address the key issue of getting efficiency into the whole process. The Industry Commission report highlighted the core problem of getting efficiency into processing and boils the problem down to the government being rusted onto an archaic industrial relations system while the rest of the world looks on in utter amazement. Clearly, the government has failed miserably to serve the best interests of our industry and to serve the best interests of Australia in addressing this problem.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.15 p.m. to 12.37 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of bills will have a profound effect on the beef industry in Australia. These are landmark pieces of legislation, very important, and I want to reiterate a few points that have been made by the opposition during this debate. The first point is that it needs to be highlighted that it has taken the government 14 months to respond to this Industry Commission report. This is not just a one-off situation as far as government responding to IC reports is concerned. The taxpayers of Australia put an enormous amount of resource into getting these professionally done and objective reports of industry analysis.

PARA.TAB: At the moment we are also waiting on a report that is with a government minister and has been for 12 months—that is, the IC report on the petroleum industry in Australia. There has still been no response from the government in that regard, yet that also has an effect on this industry. It has taken 14 months for the government to respond to this Industry Commission report. I suppose that, if we look at some of the comments and recommendations that have been made in the IC report, we can understand why it has taken the government so long to respond to the report.

The beef industry is one of Australia's most vitally important rural industries. We are very much world competitive, for reasons differing from those that the government recognises. Previous opposition speakers have passed criticism of the fact that this bill is being debated in the national parliament of Australia when the minister is overseas. We are not criticising the fact that the minister is overseas; we recognise that he has got to do that to do his job adequately in representing the rural industries of Australia. But it is probably an indication of where in the scale of the importance of things the government places the beef industry, when the government is prepared to run this legislation through in the second chamber when the minister is overseas. That needs to be put on the record. I know that there has been a fair amount of criticism levelled at the shadow minister for primary industry for making the same comments, but it is certainly worth putting it on the record that I think the government should have placed a little bit more importance on this package of legislation, which is very important to the prosperity of the beef industry.

This package of legislation is complex. I was involved in the livestock selling business and auctioneering business in a former life, and so I can understand the frustration which many of my constituents have expressed to me with regard to recent levy charges and levy changes. It can be seen that the main bill is giving effect to the Meat Industry Council, and I understand that a great many of the other bills have the effect of transferring to the Meat Industry Council the ability to charge the levies which are already being paid.

It is interesting to see which organisations are to be on the Meat Industry Council, and, indeed, the details of the composition of the council jumped off the page at me when I first read it. There are to be 18 members and the council will include a chairperson and a government member, both of whom will be appointed by the minister. The minister will also appoint other members on the recommendation of the Cattle Council of Australia, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, the Australian Meat Council, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, the Australian Lot Feeders Association, the Australian Supermarket Institute Limited and other members prescribed by regulation.

Although it is not enunciated in any of the documentation that I have read in the course of my research, I would hope that, under that last criterion of `other members prescribed by regulation', there is a representative from the Livestock Agents Association. Livestock agents are the people who, on behalf of the AMLC, and, in the future, the Meat Industry Council, collect levies. They are the people who have got to deal with the producers and explain to them what it is all about when the levy goes up. Livestock agents also have to explain how the money is being spent. Although as the collectors for the Commonwealth the livestock agents cop the blame, I do not see them listed as members of that body. I have not researched the situation any further, and they may be involved as other members prescribed by regulation. I certainly hope so.

I reiterate the absolute importance of having someone on the council who represents livestock selling agents from across Australia. There are a number of peak bodies in the states from which it would be possible to draw some very experienced people.

I do not disagree with the selection of the other representatives on the council; their selection is obviously justifiable. However, although there are producers, processors, retailers and wholesalers represented on the council, the key conduit person from the middle of the process is not represented. It does not matter whether the product is consumed domestically or whether it is exported; the fact is that a large percentage of the beef cattle in Australia which are processed through saleyards are processed through livestock selling agents. It is very important that that fact is recognised, and I hope that the government takes what I have said on board. The government has obviously left a little flexibility at the margin so that someone else in that area can be included.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions is included, and that is fine because many of the members of the union are involved in the beef industry in areas such as production and processing, transport, retailing and overseas shipment. However, do not forget a very important element: the livestock agents are the people who collect the levies for the Commonwealth in those circumstances. It is very important that livestock agents be included on the Meat Industry Council.

The government asked the Industry Commission to undertake a study into the meat industry, and the commission reported to the government in July 1994. I have already made the point that the report had been with the government for 14 months before a response and this draft legislation was received. In its report, the Industry Commission pointed out that Australia produces livestock at a very low cost by international standards. However, efficient processing is necessary if Australia is to take full advantage of our comparative advantage in livestock production. The comparative advantage in livestock production in this country comes from the producers. It does not come from anywhere else along the chain; it comes from the producers. We have the most efficient producers of beef in the world and this is because the prices that our producers receive for their product are very low by world standards. The Industry Commission report said that the reason Australia remains world competitive in this area is that processors are able to buy livestock at very low prices compared with the prices paid by processors in other countries. I can confidently state that this is a fact.

There are a lot of members on both sides of this chamber who have direct links to the beef industry in the production, wholesale or processing areas. The members concerned know that returns to beef producers have not progressed in real terms with the rest of the economy, and the members concerned all know that, in a lot of cases, returns have gone backwards. Returns are subject to the whims of the market.

This was recently borne out when US beef landed in Australia at competitive prices after cattle producers in the United States were paid 60 per cent more for their livestock than Australian farmers. There is not much room for any improvement as far as our primary producers are concerned. They are becoming world competitive.

This government has signed the GATT agreement and the World Trade Organisation comes into effect from 1 July 1995. In those agreements, as far as the reduction of tariff and subsidy is concerned, particularly in regard to primary products, it is on a percentage basis across-the-board off different bases. The Australian Commonwealth and its producers were already receiving low subsidy and low tariff protection. Off that base, in the first year we are reducing our tariffs by 20 per cent, whereas Great Britain and countries in the European Union are reducing from enormously high levels of tariff protection in excess of 100 per cent. I just do not see how we are ever going to be really competitive in that area.

The European Union and the United States of America still do not seem to be committed to the moral ethic of the Uruguay Round. Recently, the US introduced extra subsidies on dairy products into South-East Asia. It is going to be interesting to see, when the time comes, what we will do and what the World Trade Organisation will do when the US does not comply.

It is doubly difficult for our primary producers. They are not supported in a genuine way by the rest of the industry as far as reform is concerned. Reform is not happening in a number of areas. In the processing sector, it is not happening adequately or quickly, nor is it happening in the government sector—for instance, AQIS and its services. All Australian processors have committed themselves to quality assurance programs. In my electorate, a couple of processing plants have gone the whole hog and spent an enormous amount of money on quality assurance. They have their own quality assurance people in place but the number of AQIS people has not been reduced. That is a burden in itself. It adds to the high cost of the end product that is not relevant to what the producer has to put up with. The government has not responded to a number of issues from the IC report. One of the documents I was researching was interesting. It says:

While there has been an extensive consultation process leading to the introduction of this package of Bills, a major reservation can be identified. This is that the process was conducted against the background of issues raised in the Industry Commission report and the Discussion Paper and these, almost exclusively, focussed on perceived deficiencies in current arrangements, and concerns over the effectiveness of AMLC programs.

Consequently, relatively scant attention appears to have been paid to those aspects of the present meat marketing system which are operating satisfactorily. Nor has there been any indication of the tangible benefits that presumably would flow from the package or of what, if any, the costs might be.

The assertion that the proposed arrangements will provide a less regulatory operating environment for the industry is not yet supported by any evidence. While there has been a rearrangement of the roles and powers of various statutory bodies, in total the same array of objectives, functions and powers will largely endure.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the proposed arrangements do not give industry a full self-determination role in policy and industry development because of two key powers vested in the Minister. These are the power to veto/vary MIC, AMLC and MRC . . . directives with respect to performance of MIC, AMLC and MRC functions and powers. The Minister will also have a degree of influence and involvement through the likes of guidelines and approvals (such as appointments and export licences).

PARA.TAB: It remains to be seen whether or not those who want the role of the AMLC phased down or out . . . or those who wish to see statutory marketing and information continue . . . can be reconciled, particularly given the MIC's levy setting responsibility.

Given that there has to date been no commercial evaluation, or rigorous analysis of the worth of the AMLC and MRC to the meat and live-stock industry, it is possible that a minimally staffed MIC will not be able to mount well thought through proposals without the information base of the AMLC and MRC.
The Australian meat and live-stock industries have not reconciled the age-old conflict between producers and processors to the extent that has occurred in the dairy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an absolute matter of fact. They have not been reconciled. There is not a whole of industry commitment to the outcomes that we want to see achieved in the beef industry, and that is so very true.

PARA.TAB: We wholeheartedly support the arrangements that have been in place under the Kerin plan and then the Crean plan. The opposition supported the arrangements that we have moved the dairy industry into, so that it can take on the agreements that we have signed concerning the World Trade Organisation, which comes into place on 1 July this year. But we have not got that whole of industry commitment by the beef industry. There are too many tensions, there is not the commitment to the outcome and there is not the fairness of the down-flow of benefit to the people that deserve it.

We see the producers in times of drought receiving lower and lower margins. We see producers in good times, in flush times, being penalised because of corrupt overseas markets. When the market is bad, the people that bear the brunt of it are not the processing plants or the people that work in the processing plants, they are not the transport operators or the shipping people that take the containers over the wharves. Who are they? It is the producers that bear the brunt of it. Instead of getting $400 for a beast, they get $200 for a beast and have got to shut up and take it. They have absolutely no redress at all because those producers might have one sale a year. They might breed weaners for sale into a fattening market, and they have one sale a year. If that sale happens to fall in a time of low prices, they have no choice but to take what they are offered.

That illustrates that there is no commitment right across the industry to see fair and equitable distribution of the profits of the industry back to the people who produce the goods and the other people involved in the industry who have got major investment. Without the producers, without the processors, the employees along the way would not have the jobs that they have got. It is very important that in the industry, and at this level of setting industry policy, these facts are recognised. To date I do not believe they are.
It is interesting to note the amendment that has been moved by the shadow minister. I will put it on the record again:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Main Committee deplores the fact that the Government has implemented only one of the Industry Commission's recommendations for the industry and has ignored the others, including important recommendations relating to industrial relations reform and the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service".
I have covered both those points in my address this afternoon and I go back to the other main points that I started with as far as this vitally important industry is concerned.

PARA.TAB: It has taken all that time for the government to respond, in drafting this legislation, to that IC report; the government has addressed only a couple of the recommendations in that IC report; and it is running this legislation through the national parliament of Australia with the minister overseas. I am not decrying the fact that he is actually overseas working on behalf of the producers of Australia. I am just pointing out that the scheduling of this legislation when he is not here is an indication to us on this side of the House of the level of importance that the government places on this industry, which is absolutely vital. We are not seeing a genuine attitude towards all the government members' constituents that work in this industry, to try to see the ongoing viability of the industry and to see a fair and equitable distribution of the profits that flow from this industry in Australia.

Most important is the fact that, in all the documentation that I have read, there does not seem to be any reference to the possibility of having a representative of any of the livestock agents associations around Australian represented on the Meat Industry Council. They are an absolutely vital link in the chain in this industry in Australia. They are the people who actually collect all the levies that this legislation is putting into place, for the Meat Industry Council to collect. They are the people with whom the bureaucrats in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy should be liaising. They should be told, `This is how you explain it to the producers. This is what we were are doing with the money. It is all about making sure that our product maintains a very high reputation overseas.'

We all agree with that sentiment. We agree with what has been done. The producers do not know that; that message is not getting across. The message is not getting down to those livestock agents. I implore the government to have a look at that particular area under the category `other members prescribed by regulation' so that there is some representative of the livestock agents to give them input into what is going to be a very important body in the future.
