DEBATE.TITLE: AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY BILL 1995Cognate bill:AIRCRAFT NOISE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 11 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.
The purpose of this bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on jet aircraft landings at airports where noise amelioration programs are being funded by the federal government.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will be aware that construction of a new parallel runway at Sydney airport was completed during 1994, and the runway came into operation in November 1994. When the recently installed air traffic control system is operating at full capacity, the traffic handling capacity of the new runway configuration will be about 80 aircraft movements per hour, compared with 55 movements per hour prior to the commissioning of the new runway.

While the operation of the new parallel runway configuration significantly reduces the overall number of people seriously affected by aircraft noise, particularly among those to the east and west of the airport, it significantly increases the level of noise exposure for residents of some other areas, mainly to the north of the airport. Recognising that this would be the case, the government, in 1991, commissioned a steering committee, convened by the Federal Airports Corporation, to prepare a noise management plan for Sydney airport, identifying possible measures to mitigate the noise impact of the new runway operation.

A draft noise management plan was subsequently developed, with extensive involvement by the three levels of government, the community and the airline industry. The draft plan was released for public comment in June 1994. After considering measures proposed in the draft noise management plan, the government announced late last year that it would undertake a major program of acquisition and acoustic insulation of certain buildings in the areas worst affected by noise from the operation of the airport. In addition, the government has initiated a range of other measures, including mandatory flight paths, take-off procedures for jet aircraft and tighter curfew arrangements, to minimise the number of people affected by aircraft noise.

The acquisition and insulation program encompasses the voluntary acquisition of up to 113 residential properties within the 40 ANEF zone; sound insulation of some 4,200 residential properties within the 30 ANEF zone; and sound insulation of schools and colleges, child-care facilities, hospitals and health care facilities and churches within the 25 ANEF zone.

The scope of eligibility for this program is at least equal to that at any major overseas airport where a noise amelioration program is in place. It is the government's intention that the announced program be completed within a three-year period. This, again, compares favourably with the rate of implementation of overseas programs.

Based on indicative cost data developed in conjunction with the draft noise management plan, the cost of the program was originally estimated at some $183 million. Following a reassessment of eligible buildings and the scope and cost of required works, the estimated overall cost of the program is now $260 million, in 1995-96 prices.

The airlines and their passengers will be the beneficiaries of the increased runway capacity created at Sydney airport. It follows that they should be required to meet the cost of reducing the noise impacts on the affected communities in the vicinity of the airport. The levy which this bill seeks to impose will provide the means for giving effect to this principle.
The bill provides that the levy will apply only at declared airports, which are those where the following conditions apply:
. there are residences or public buildings in noise affected areas (as defined by ANEF contours) around the airport,
. there is or has been a federal government funded airport noise amelioration program in place, and
. the amount of levy collected at a given time is not in excess of the costs to the federal government of the noise amelioration program.

The levy will apply, in the first instance, to Sydney airport only. This recognises the very significant change in noise patterns around the airport which results from the opening of the new runway. The government similarly expects that, where new runway developments or extensions enabling a significant change in either the number or type of jet aircraft usages occur at other major airports, the need for noise amelioration programs will also arise.

Honourable members will be aware that the government has embarked on a program of leasing federal airports. As part of the next stage of the disposal process, the government will examine how best to ensure responsible environmental behaviour by users and operators of leased airports.

Prospective airport operators will clearly have an interest in the development of environmental management measures, including noise amelioration, which may be warranted by significant runway works and changes in operations at the airports which they will be leasing. These leases will, therefore, be addressed in the context of the airport leasing program which will see the first of our major federal airports leased in 1996.

Turning to the levy itself, the amount of levy payable per jet aircraft landing will be determined according to a formula developed as part of the Sydney airport draft noise management plan. The formula provides that the noisier an aircraft the higher will be the rate of levy payable per landing. For example, the amount of levy payable for a landing by a Boeing 747 will be some three to four times higher than for a Boeing 737, depending on the specific noise characteristics of the particular aircraft.

The bill provides for the levy to apply to landings by jet aircraft only. This reflects the fact that generally jet aircraft create greater noise disturbance than propeller driven aircraft. There will be some quiet small jet aircraft which are not liable for the levy.

It is a requirement of the bill that revenue from the levy at a particular declared airport not exceed the cost of the noise amelioration program at that airport. To spread the cost impact on airlines, it is not envisaged that the levy will necessarily be raised at a rate which keeps pace with spending on the noise amelioration program. The levy rate will be prescribed by regulations subject to the limitations established in the bill.

It is proposed that there will be automatic annual adjustments of the levy rates in line with consumer price index movements. The rate will also be periodically reviewed in the light of other parameters, such as growth rates in jet aircraft landings and the cost of noise amelioration programs that might be established at any other airports.

It is the government's intention that the rate of levy be initially set at an amount of $155 per noise unit. This rate will be adjusted as necessary so as to enable the cost of the Sydney airport noise amelioration program to be recovered over a period of up to 10 years. In 1995-96 it is expected that the levy will raise some $32.2 million. This translates to an average cost per jet aircraft passenger landing at Sydney airport of around $3.40.

This is a landmark bill. It establishes a regime for recovering from aviation operators the costs of redressing the adverse impact of aircraft noise imposed on communities in the vicinity of airports, immediately in the case of Sydney airport and at other Australian airports in future years.

In respect of the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill, the purpose of this bill is to establish a collection regime for the levy imposed by the complementary Aircraft Noise Levy Bill. The levy collection bill specifies in detail by whom, in what circumstances, and when and how the levy is payable. It also covers penalty and enforcement arrangements and provides the necessary powers to allow the levy to be collected by a Commonwealth authority. It is proposed that the Civil Aviation Authority, or Airservices Australia when it is established, will perform this role.

Since the processes for collection of the noise levy readily dovetail with the authority's own revenue collection activities based on aircraft landings, it is expected that this arrangement will minimise administrative costs associated with the collection of the levy. I commend both bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, this House condemns the Government for its callous and incompetent policy on Sydney Airport, and condemns it in particular:
(a)for its decision effectively to close the east west runway;
(b)for misleading the people of Sydney about the noise that would be associated with the opening of the parallel runway; and
(c)for its failure to develop adequate noise management measures prior to the opening of the parallel runway, rather than after it opened in a belated response to community pressure".

I rise on behalf of Senator Parer—who is our shadow minister for aviation and who has responsibility for carriage of this bill through the Senate—and, indeed, on behalf of the opposition generally. I take this opportunity to move my first amendment; I will be moving a second amendment relating to the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill at a later time, when we deal with the bill in detail.

PARA.TAB: This amendment probably bests expresses the views held by many people in Sydney today about the disaster that has been over their heads every day of the year since the opening of the third runway—or the second parallel runway—at Sydney's Mascot airport. I do not think there is a soul living in Sydney—nor, indeed, in New South Wales—who would not be affected by the concerns which these people in Sydney have been drawing to our attention as a consequence of the dramatic increase in noise over the heads of many thousands of people in Sydney since the second parallel runway was opened in the latter months of last year.

We have seen on television, right across the nation, demonstrations being lead by community leaders in Sydney—demonstrations complaining about the poor management of aircraft noise as a consequence of the opening of the second parallel runway, and demonstrations about the lies and deceit concerning the effects of the opening of the second parallel runway that have been given to the people of Sydney by this government.

It is amazing to think that it was not until after the second parallel runway was opened by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) late last year that people became aware of the noise patterns that were to be created by the opening of that new runway and the effect that those noise patterns would have on the lives of Sydneysiders. People were not properly informed about the amount of noise and the places that that noise would impact upon throughout Sydney. As a consequence, some hundreds of thousands of people are adversely affected.

I know the government drags out a figure of around 110,000 or 120,000 people affected by the second parallel runway. But figures have been put to me in recent days that indicate that some 600,000 people have been adversely affected by the second parallel runway's being opened late last year. I do not live in Sydney, but I live in a regional area outside of Sydney. I have relatives and friends who live in Sydney. When I go there, it is the topic of conversation that those people first raise with me. It is absolutely amazing to evaluate the impact that this has had on the lives of ordinary citizens living in Sydney.

The thing that outrages them more than anything else is the fact that the people of Sydney were not adequately informed about the impact that this noise would have on them and the areas that this noise would impact upon. They believe—and we, in the opposition, agree with them—that they were lied to and were not provided with adequate information.

I think there would be many people, not just on this side of the House but also on the other side of the House, who would agree that the proper information that should have been provided by the government was not provided to people in Sydney. It is for that reason that so many people are upset—upset because they were not properly informed but were lied to, and upset because for the first time in their lives they now have aircraft noise right over their heads, at levels that nobody had ever envisaged. It is for that reason that we have seen those demonstrations, which continue to this day and, I dare say, will continue beyond today despite the passage of this legislation through our parliament.

The reason why I suspect there will be further demonstrations is exhibited on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald, which publishes a very timely leak to the newspaper detailing the government's proposals to further expand Sydney airport. That will ultimately increase the operations at Sydney airport and ultimately increase the noise over the heads of people living in Sydney. This will further fire up demonstrations of concern by people in Sydney because yet again the government, through the Federal Airports Corporation and, indeed, the Civil Aviation Authority, is not telling the people of Sydney the truth about the second parallel runway.

While I speak about not telling the truth about the second parallel runway, I might make the point also that the government is not telling the truth about its decision to close the east-west runway. Sydney has had a north-south, east-west runway operation at Mascot airport for as long as people can remember. The east-west runway was closed with the opening of the second parallel runway late last year. One of the reasons people are so upset is that, with the closure of the east-west runway, people who have bought their houses and lived their lives with the expectation that they will have aircraft noise over their heads and have paid a price—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute rubbish.

—The honourable member for Watson may say that it is absolute rubbish, but I will make the point to this chamber that the deal that was struck to get the second parallel runway—the third runway—at Sydney's Mascot airport was struck at the time by the now Prime Minister in a deal that ensured support from his fellow Sydney members on the basis that when the second parallel runway, the third runway—
—That's an absolute lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —was built, the east-west runway would be closed. That would advantage certain members of the Labor Party in Sydney.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would like the honourable member to withdraw the imputation that the Prime Minister and I and the minister were in some sort of deal. —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member for Watson is the next speaker in this debate and will have ample opportunity to say whatever he likes about his own actions. I think that—
—I think the honourable member for Watson is aware of that. That is no point of order.

—The honourable member for Hume might resume his seat. I will take it from there. There is no point of order, and the honourable member for Watson obviously will have a chance to respond on any things that have been said by the honourable member for Hume in his debate.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my point is that I made a point of order specifically under the standing orders, which provide that a member cannot make imputations against another member unless it is done by substantive motion. The honourable member for Hume suggested that I was involved in some sort of shabby deal on this, which is an imputation against me. If he says that he is not making that imputation, that is fine, but if that is the imputation he is making I have the right under the standing orders to require that it be withdrawn. If he says that he is not making that imputation I am quite happy for the proceedings to continue.
—The honourable member for Hume did not refer to any honourable members by their title, hence the reason I have ruled the way I have.

—In fact, the only person I mentioned by title or by name was the Prime Minister. The honourable member for Watson is showing his sensitivity on this issue, and perhaps there is also a sense of guilt.
—Absolutely not. I am just trying to keep you honest.

—I tell you what, it is an easy job to keep me honest. I will come back for the speech of the honourable member for Watson and take a number of points of order to take up some of his time in return for the interruption to my speech.
—The honourable member for Hume is not suggesting that he is going to make trivial points of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, it was a deal, and it was struck for political purposes for political gain. The people of Sydney know this. It has even been reported in a book. I do not need to mention any names because it has become folklore in parts of Sydney as to the reasons for this. It has been put by the government, and by the minister in particular, that, in addition to those reasons outlined by the honourable member for Watson, the closure is for safety reasons. It is said that we cannot have an intersecting runway operation at Sydney airport now that we have a second parallel runway. That is pure bunkum.

PARA.TAB: We have lived with intersecting runway operations at Sydney airport for as long as anybody can remember. Major airports around the world, bigger than Sydney's Mascot airport, some of the biggest airports in the world—indeed, the biggest airport in the world—have intersecting runway operations as part of their normal runway operations. They manage to operate those safely, efficiently and effectively. The net consequence of closing the east-west runway has concentrated a great deal of noise over a substantial part of Sydney that never expected it.

That is why people are fired up in Sydney. That is why they are arguing against the government. That is why they are making accusations that the government did not inform them adequately. That is why they are having demonstrations. As I was saying a moment ago, I expect that there will be more demonstrations because a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald says that there are plans to expand the Mascot operations through the addition of a number of buildings to increase the capacity of Mascot airport in the near future.

The government has not told us much about that, just as it has not told us much about the new control tower at Mascot airport. The new control tower was supposed to open before the New South Wales election. It was conveniently delayed until Easter. Due to some technical failure, which we have become used to when talking about operations managed by the Civil Aviation Authority, the control tower is still not in operation.

Mr Buck Brooksbank, the acting chief executive officer of the Civil Aviation Authority, says that nobody can give a date for when the control tower will be in operation and therefore able to alleviate some of the problems that we have been told it will alleviate. So Sydneysiders will have to live with these problems for longer than they were told they would prior to the New South Wales election.

I believe that Sydneysiders will be living with these problems for longer than this government is prepared to admit, because this government is relying heavily upon its so-called fast-tracking of the Badgerys Creek airport—the Sydney West airport, as it is called. The government says, `Do not worry, we'll solve these problems for you. Vote for us at the next election because we have got the formula to reduce the noise over Sydney by fast-tracking the construction of Badgerys Creek airport.' The only thing that is fast about Badgerys Creek airport is the talk. We are getting a lot of fast talking from the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and a lot of slow tracking on Badgerys Creek.

Years after this government promised that Badgerys Creek airport would be opened, we still have not seen anything happen out at Badgerys Creek. There has been a steady march of transport ministers since this government came into office in 1983. Over that time, various transport ministers or ministers for aviation have made specific predictions about the completion of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. The last minister before the current minister, Senator Bob Collins, made a specific commitment as to the completion date of Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. That date passed by long ago. Yet this government, the present minister and the Prime Minister are asking the people of Sydney to believe their current speculations about the opening of Sydney West airport within the next few years.

On the basis of its track record on Badgerys Creek airport, the government cannot be believed. I believe the only thing that is happening at Sydney West airport is some fast talking and not much action. We are going to find that the people of Sydney will be bothered by these noise problems for a lot longer than the government is prepared to admit. My colleague Senator Parer provided me with some information that was revealed by the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority in its report on aircraft noise. The Environment Protection Authority concluded that many suburbs, including Kurnell, Bundeena and Rozelle, were experiencing annoyingly high levels of aircraft noise, despite the claim in the noise management plan that they would not be affected. In one street the noise level exceeded 80 decibels 26 times an hour and the residents living in that street do not qualify for the insulation program, despite the Australian standard that noise levels in homes should not exceed 60 decibels.

That points to the fact that the bill does not deal adequately with the problems of noise for many thousands of Sydneysiders. Even for those Sydneysiders who do qualify for soundproofing of their buildings, schools and homes, this will not resolve all the problems. There have been some 3,000 submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney. Many of the submissions, which were made by 3,000 residents, are very sceptical about the soundproofing program. For example, one of them said that the recommendation to soundproof buildings and schools is only a partial solution, and that Sydney's mild climate lends itself to outdoor living. What happens when people or children move outside? Do they have insulated space helmets?

This is not going to completely solve the problem of aircraft noise for Sydneysiders. At best, it will only partially solve the problem for some of the people who are affected by noise levels from Sydney airport and as a consequence of the second parallel runway being open.

I thank my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) for pointing out to me the other day that there are some rather unusual discrepancies in the way in which the levy for particular aircraft is going to work. He makes the point that the levy actually penalises the quietest jets at the expense of not penalising the noisiest jets as much. For example, a BAe146 will have a levy that is the equivalent of $5.17 per passenger, whereas a 747-400 will have a levy of $3.67 per passenger.

Anybody who knows anything about aircraft will tell people that a BAe146 is probably the quietest commercial jet aircraft operating in and out of Sydney at the present time. If I were a resident of Sydney concerned about noise levels, I would want to ensure that the government was doing its utmost to encourage the use of the quietest possible aircraft, given that Sydney airport is going to be a reality for many years. Indeed, the levy on the quietest jet aircraft, that is, the BAe146, is the highest of all the jet passenger aircraft that operate into Sydney's airport.

The honourable member for Fadden will go on and explain that in far greater detail in his speech later today, but it is rather inconsistent to be doing it in this fashion. As I say, if I were a resident of Sydney with aircraft roaring over my head, I would want to be encouraging the use of the BAe146 by having either no levy imposed or at least the lightest levy per passenger imposed on that type of aircraft rather than the opposite, which is the way the government has done it.

The bill reflects the failure of the government to adequately manage the air traffic noise over Sydney airport. There has been very poor planning in the way in which the government has been developing its air traffic noise management proposals. For example, the original plan was to take 10 years to provide insulation for homes in Sydney that are severely affected by aircraft noise as a result of the second parallel runway.

Whilst I am talking about insulation, I will make a little plug for my constituents, who are wool producers. Wool is one of the best forms of sound insulation available today. There is a gentleman in Goulburn who is going to insulate, free of charge, a number of houses—I think one of them is in Rozelle. Some of them might be in the electorate of the honourable member for Watson—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nowhere near us.

—I know Rozelle is nowhere near you, but that gentleman will be working in a number of suburbs around Sydney—one of which I hope will be in the honourable member for Watson's electorate—because he is convinced, as are many people, that wool is one of the most effective sound insulation materials available. I would urge the FAC, and anyone responsible for these insulation programs, to take into account the value of wool. It is extremely valuable in controlling and minimising the effects of noise.

PARA.TAB: There are many concerns raised by Sydneysiders, which are not adequately dealt with in this legislation. The government's propaganda about fast-tracking Badgerys Creek does not fool too many people. Its propaganda about narrowing the flight paths and introducing heavy penalties for those people who breach those flight paths is not going to solve the problem. People know that pilots go where they are told to go. Air traffic control tells the pilots to take a particular heading and to follow a particular track. The trumpeting by the minister, late last year and early this year, of his method of solving the aircraft noise problems over Sydney by having heavy fines for pilots who do not adhere to those flight paths, is going to do very little indeed to solve the problems of aircraft noise resulting from the expansion of Sydney's Mascot airport.

It is an issue of considerable concern. My colleague in the Senate Senator Parer, our shadow minister for aviation, will be making very strong representations in the Senate on this issue. I know other members in this House will also be making representations to try to do their best to bring some honesty and openness into the way in which this government deals with the people of Sydney over the aircraft noise problem. I can tell the House—as would the honourable member for Watson, who represents many people in Sydney—that this problem is destroying the lives of people in Sydney. The noise is incredible. I have actually been to some of these places, where the aircraft noise rattles the houses. My mother-in-law lives out in Castle Hill. That might seem a long way from Sydney's airport. Yet, for the first time ever, aircraft are flying over her house and destroying the lifestyle of the people living out there.

This problem is affecting a very wide area of Sydney, previously never affected by aircraft noise. The people in those areas have a just argument; they bought or built their houses on the basis that they were not under a flight path. They paid prices for their houses that reflected the fact that those parts of Sydney were supposed to be quiet areas. Consequently, the value of their homes has been reduced. All Sydney's federal parliamentary representatives have to be very pro-active on this issue. I hope that they will be. They certainly should be, if they are to represent the interests of their constituents to the best of their abilities .

The opposition calls on the government to be open and honest about what is going to happen at Sydney airport; to provide the public with the full details of this latest expansion proposal as revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald today; to provide the public with the truth about what is happening at Badgerys Creek airport because we are not getting the truth on that; to provide the public with the truth about the noise contours over Sydney; to provide the public with the truth as to the actual numbers of people who are affected by this; to do everything within its power to encourage the use of the quietest possible aircraft; and to ensure that the Civil Aviation Authority—or the new Airservices Australia as it will be known after 1 July—is effective in administering the air laws in a way that minimises the impact of noise over the heads of Sydney people. I can tell members now that a lot of people are very sceptical about the way in which this government has been approaching the whole issue of airports in Sydney and at Badgerys Creek and the whole issue of noise pollution over the heads of hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders.

We will not, of course, be opposing this bill. The opposition is keen to do whatever is possible to assist in minimising the impact of noise over the heads of Sydney people as a consequence of this government's actions, so we will not be opposing it. I moved our amendment earlier in my presentation this afternoon. When we deal with the bill in detail, I will be moving an additional amendment that I have yet to refer to that deals with the incremental increase in the levy.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Is the amendment seconded?

—In my opinion, this bill should never have been necessary because the third runway at Sydney airport, the parallel runway, should never have been built. The member for Barton and I got up everywhere we could and said to people, `Just be aware of what this means to you. Just be aware of the disaster that this is going to make of your lives.' But what did the New South Wales Liberals, their National Party cohorts and the crooks in the FAC say? They said, `No, no, let's have this. Let's have it now.'

Of course, if that is what the opposition wants and if that is what the opposition gets, maybe they should also have read what the EIS said, because the building of the parallel runway at Sydney airport was predicated on the downgrading of the east-west runway. That information is in the EIS that the FAC put forward. For people to say, `Now that it has been built you have to go and reopen the east-west runway for continuous traffic,' is a duplicitous joke that these people are trying to inflict on the people of Sydney.

The involvement of the New South Wales Liberals and their National Party cohorts was revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 December 1994 when an article detailed just how involved the former Premier and his colleagues in the coalition are. Members might recall the article, which was headed `Greiner pushed for third runway'. The article followed the release of all the New South Wales government documents on the parallel runway proposal.

The New South Wales Liberals, according to the article, conducted a comprehensive campaign pushing for a third Sydney runway. The documents show that the former Minister for Tourism, Mr Garry West, a colleague of the member for Hume, who just spoke, advocated the easing of the curfew, as did his colleague, the member for Fadden, who will speak next.

The documents make it increasingly difficult for the government in New South Wales at the time—the Liberal government—to distance itself from any decision to build the third runway, that is, the parallel runway at Sydney airport. Indeed, it has since been revealed that the Liberals even hired a PR firm to run their campaign for them. This is one of the most scurrilous episodes in the operation of the Greiner-Fahey government. Even though it is supported by the federal opposition now, the Liberals are trying to turn it around by saying, `What the federal government did is terrible.'

Unfortunately, the government was overwhelmed by the media campaign which was pushed by the Liberals, the FAC and industry. As were a number of my colleagues, I am on the public record as saying that it is a mistake. I said that the government should never have done these things and that the government should never have built the parallel runway.

I have also said publicly that the people in the Federal Airports Corporation are a disgrace. They have lied to the public and misled the government. It is shown again today in the Sydney Morning Herald that the FAC is not telling people what its plans are. There has been more duplicity and dishonesty by officials in relation to Sydney airport than in any other exercise in government in the 16 years I have been in this House. It is an ongoing saga of lies and deceit from this GBE.

The FAC had the hide to say at one stage that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) ought to let the FAC bid to buy Sydney airport when the airport is privatised. That is like letting the crooks take over the treasury. The FAC set this thing up, and now it wants the management to buy out the buyer. Fortunately, the minister decided that he is not going to let that scam occur.

The opposition now say, `It's terrible. It's shocking.' The opposition say that, even though the opposition is part of the problem but not part of the solution. It is a sick joke. After all, it is people like the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who, all of a sudden, has discovered aircraft noise. He says, `Isn't it terrible? Share the pain. Open the east-west runway.' Of course, when we talked about this earlier—when the proposal was that the government should build the parallel runway and when the government put forward the idea that Badgerys Creek ought to be developed quickly as an alternate airport to Sydney airport—the member for Bennelong and his constituents did not like it. This is because, when we look at the studies of where air travellers come from in Sydney, we find a great little concentration of air travellers in the electorate of Bennelong. Travellers from this area do not want to spend a bit of time travelling out to the western suburbs of Sydney to catch their aeroplanes, and they say, `Oh, it's inconvenient to have to do that.' I say to them that there is no point in their saying that it is inconvenient to travel that far, just as there is no point in their saying now how inconvenient it is that the poor old real estate prices have fallen and that it is inconvenient to have the planes flying over their heads.

As I said earlier, these people are part of the problem, never part of the solution. What we are hearing now is something which is an unfortunate latter-day conversion on the road to Sydney or Badgerys Creek, depending upon how people want to look at it. If only the opposition—and, indeed, the government—had been able to look at this a bit more carefully. If only members of parliament from all parties had not just been belly-aching and whingeing about how terrible it was that they had to spend 10 minutes circling Sydney airport on Friday afternoon on the way home from parliament, and how awful it was and how we had to get this parallel runway up.

They were conned by the FAC that that was going to solve their problem, and they were conned by the airlines. One of the great little hypocritical stories in this is that now we hear the bleatings from Qantas, our so-called wonderful national carrier. These are the people who never did any planning for what they did at Sydney airport, and all they want to do now is belly-ache about how terrible it is that the previous Liberal government gave Ansett all the land leases and that they do not have anything there.

Yet they have the hide to say that if the government had done some earlier planning about Badgerys Creek then we would not have the problem at Sydney airport. Qantas did not do all that much planning, either. Qantas has not got any land, and its management is in the paper today saying they might have a plan to move their maintenance facility to Brisbane or to Melbourne because the government did not do something. It is the stupidity of the Qantas management in getting into bed with the Federal Airports Corporation and with Ansett in saying the solution to Sydney's airport needs was at Sydney airport with the parallel runway, rather than looking at what happened everywhere else in the world. Everywhere else, there are big airports out on the city rim and smaller airports close to the city, like Kingsford Smith is in Sydney.

The reality of this is that the lives of tens of thousands of people in Sydney have been destroyed, and they have been destroyed by politicians on both sides of this House who were short-sighted. They have been destroyed, in particular, by the duplicity and the lying and the dishonesty of the Federal Airports Corporation, the government's own GBE, which allowed these things to happen and did not inform ministers or the public of what it was up to. Its program was always to build everything it possibly could at Sydney airport; and it was aided and abetted by the airlines, which said that the last thing they wanted to do was to move out to Badgerys Creek.

James Strong, who allegedly works for the government as the head of a government GBE, says that Qantas's solution to Sydney airport is that everyone else ought to move out. We should get the commuters out of there, and get the charter operators out of there. Essentially, Sydney airport—Kingsford Smith airport—should become Kingsford Smith (Qantas) airport, and everyone else should go out to Badgerys Creek.

The reality is that this legislation will provide some funds so that the problem can be ameliorated. The people who are using the aircraft will pay some money towards trying to ameliorate some of the noise pollution that is hitting the tens of thousands of people who live around Sydney airport—many of whom I represent now, and a great deal more of whom I represented when I was the member for Grayndler.

There are very few people in this House who have clean hands on this issue. The member for Barton, the member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh), the member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), the minister and I are a few of the ones who have, because we stood up and said how crook this thing was. At least the people who are going to cause the noise are going to have to pay for some of it now, and I think that is a fair thing.

To my mind, one of the few ministers in this country who have actually had some thought about the people who lived around the airport has been the federal transport minister. One of the others was the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). They at least had a concern for the effect that this monstrosity was going to have on the people who lived around the airport. All the other belly-aching MPs from both sides would come back here on Tuesday mornings and tell me, `We had to queue up at Sydney airport again on Friday night. Isn't it terrible?' Bad luck. Isn't it terrible that we have inconvenienced some of them? They all lobbied and went mad down here.

The people who live in Marrickville, where I grew up, are actually going mad—literally going mad over this. They have these planes day and night. There are some people in the opposition who say that is not enough, we have to open it up for 24-hour operations. The government is not going to do that. The EIS was predicated on not reopening the east-west runway for continual traffic, and at least what this levy will do is ensure that part of the problem funds part of the solution.

I might sound a little passionate about this, but I do believe that there has been a terrible injustice perpetrated in Sydney. A vast part of the greatest city in this country—indeed, one of the great cities in the world—has been destroyed by this parallel runway set-up at Sydney airport. I am truly of the belief that, if the Federal Airports Corporation had been open and had not concealed the truth about the effect this would have on the people of Sydney, no government would ever have built this monstrosity. But the truth did not come out until after it was done, and no-one is going to say to a government, `You spent some billions of dollars on this proposal and you have to pull it up.'

Where is the FAC now? It is where its plan always was: increase the capital structure and no-one will be able to do anything about it. While the government is saying it wants to try to move traffic out to Badgerys Creek, what is the good old FAC doing? It had plans leaked today. Of course, you cannot believe all that you read in the Sydney Morning Herald, but on some of these issues it has been right. If it is to be believed, the FAC has another plan to spend another $500 million at Sydney airport. This will make it absolutely impossible, when the Olympics come around, for anyone to sustain an argument that says, `Do not do away with the curfew.'

Some of the things that have been done in this business verge on the criminal. The effect it has had on the lives of the people in my electorate verges on the obscene. I think at least this will help them a bit. It is not going to help them much, but at least the minister has got to the stage where he is trying to do something for the people who are affected by the airport. Now we have the opposition saying, `Isn't this terrible? The government should never have done it.' Crikey, this is the greatest case of amnesia I have witnessed in my life!

My dear friend the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), from the north coast of New South Wales, was in favour of this proposal because he wanted to do the best thing for his constituents. He wanted commuter airlines to be able to fly into Sydney airport. When he travels on Qantas next time, he ought to find out from James Strong what his plan is for the commuters from his electorate, because his plan is to get rid of them—they are a nuisance, so get rid of them. This whole scam has been run by the FAC for the two big airlines and a whole lot of other people have been sucked into it—some for good intentions, like country members, and others, like John Fahey and Nick Greiner, for their own political reasons.

I think that everyone ought to very closely scrutinise anything that goes on at Sydney airport in the future, because the one thing to look back on is that what the member for Barton and I said is true. What we said would happen has happened. Everyone said at the time that we were misguided scaremongers. We were probably conservative, because it has turned out to be even worse than we thought. It was pretty hard to find anyone who thought worse than this for the last 10 years than the member for Barton and I.

On that note I might finish. I commend the legislation to the House and I would suggest to all members that they very carefully scrutinise anything that goes on at Sydney airport. What I have said is not an attack on the minister, who I think has done more than anyone else to try to alleviate the suffering of the people around the airport, it is not even an attack on previous transport ministers on either side of the House, but it certainly is an attack on the government's advisers. The FAC knew and it kept quiet, because it was an organisation that had been captured by its client group, the airline industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some aspects of the contribution made by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) with which I agree and which I will expand on in terms of the future of this particular piece of legislation. There are other aspects, of course, where he was right out. I categorically deny that I ever mentioned lifting a curfew on Sydney airport. I think the honourable member will find that that was a ploy that was leaked by a Labor Party operative who misquoted a letter that I once wrote to him regarding the future of aircraft noise. I was pointing out in that letter that aircraft were getting quieter and quieter and that by about the year 2025 we may not have conventional aircraft, as such, operating. That aside, the opposition is not going to oppose the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: I have a great deal of sympathy with what the member for Watson said in terms of some of the information that was given out regarding the effects of the opening of that third runway. This is but a very small way of trying to amend that particular situation. I want to give the honourable member for Watson some advice so that he can go in with his minister now and start getting things right for Badgerys Creek. There is absolutely nothing wrong with a major airport being on the edge of town, which Sydney West will be. The secret to the success of that particular airport will be the infrastructure, and the provision of fast and rapid transport to get in and out.

Let us look at some of the major airports being developed now around the world. The Denver international airport, which opened a few months ago, is about 52 miles out of the city and it has plans for a high speed rail link. More importantly, I suggest that the honourable member for Watson have a look at Stansted Airport in the UK which is coming on stream as London's No. 3 airport. It is interesting in that Stansted is an identical distance from the middle of London as Badgerys Creek is from the middle of Sydney. With the British Rail link that operates there, it is possible to get from Stansted to Liverpool Street Station, in the heart of London, in 42 minutes. Now, that is not a bad trip. Quite often, especially in the morning periods, it is almost impossible to get from Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport to the centre of the city in 42 minutes. The secret to it is that infrastructure: it has got to be high speed and it has probably got to be high speed rail.

I was almost going to use an expression which would be politically unacceptable when saying that we can talk a lot about the development of Sydney West airport but, until such time as we get the infrastructure in place, we are not going to maximise the potential of that particular airport. There is no doubt that with the development of traffic coming into Australia, and into Sydney in particular, there will be a need for two airports. The reality is that about 62 per cent of the total air traffic in and out of Australia is going to use Sydney either for arrival or departure. With the expansion of airline services to Australia, and with things such as the Olympic Games coming up, there is no doubt that we will require those two facilities. It must be done properly this time so that, hopefully, we will never again see the situation that has developed in Sydney.

This particular legislation is very much about Sydney airport. We heard the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) say in his second reading speech today that we have to have declared airports before these formulae for noise alleviation come into play. I would like to inform the government that there are a number of airports that will have to be declared in a hurry. If we are to look at the noise problems around Australia, may I suggest that the officials responsible have a very quick look at the approach path to Coolangatta. I am sure the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) will be talking about that a little later.

I would also like to expose what has been happening in terms of Brisbane airport. What the honourable member for Watson was saying about government advisers is really quite interesting. There has been quite a lobby group on the south side of Brisbane for many years now who complained about aircraft noise when the new international airport in Brisbane opened in 1988. Seven years later there are still problems. As we see in this bill, there is a specific formula for determining what constitutes a badly noise affected area that would then allow people and institutions to take advantage of the bill. The magic figure is 60 decibels which, in technical terms, applies to 25 ANEFs. This particular group in Brisbane has been advised by Dr R.V. Dubs, the general manager of planning and development in the Civil Aviation Authority, that, as far as it is concerned, it would appear that Brisbane does not have these problems and that there are not any areas in the flight paths that would qualify for this sort of assistance.

The reality is that there have been a number of studies done on noise exposure distribution in Brisbane, and it is quite interesting when the facts come to light. I would like to quote, as a couple of examples, studies that were done in April and June of last year in two very badly affected areas—namely, around the Tingalpa school and also at Cannon Hill. I would want to place particular emphasis on Cannon Hill because it is proposed to develop the area there that once contained the Brisbane abattoir by building something like 12,000 new dwellings. The Queensland state government and the Brisbane City Council seem to be pretty anxious to have 12,000 new dwellings put on that particular space.

But the interesting thing about that particular location at Cannon Hill is that a noise monitor has been put nearby. In a particular period, from April to June last year, some very interesting figures came through. During that period there were 3,037 aircraft movements in that region. Of these 3,037 aircraft movements, no fewer than 2,857 of them registered above the 70 decibel mark—between 70 and 90 decibels. If the Queensland government is going to proceed with that housing development of 12,000 new dwellings, somebody is going to have a problem in terms of providing the insulation and the noise reduction facilities there. About 61.5 per cent of the traffic at that time actually broke the legal limit and, of course, while that is referring particularly to that new development site, Cannon Hill is one of those areas which are badly affected by aircraft noise.

The second study was done at the Tingalpa state school, and bear in mind the CAA says that there are no areas that actually qualify for any of this assistance under its formula. In that period, from April to June last year, at the Tingalpa state school there were 4,249 movements of which 2,447 were registered as being above 70 decibels, or 56.5 per cent of the total. At this stage, this legislation is designed strictly for Sydney, but the reality has to be faced that places such as the south side of Brisbane have some real problems.

Of course, one of the reasons that the CAA says that there are no problems in Brisbane is that aeroplanes are supposed to follow their designated flight paths. The official CAA map is really quite interesting because it shows where those aircraft should go. In fact, there is a noise monitoring facility at Princess Street in Morningside and another one at Tingalpa. There are some on the north side. But it is true that it is not uncommon for aeroplanes approaching Brisbane, especially from the north, to be two or three kilometres away from their designated flight paths.

In the very area where I live it is quite interesting because the southerly flight path is a couple of kilometres away from my home and I have watched those aircraft approach. There is a flight path that comes in from New Zealand over the Redland Bay beacon and I can watch that. They are the designated flight paths, but an awful lot of aeroplanes fly straight over the top of our place. That does not particularly worry me. I quite enjoy it, actually. I set up my monitor and I listen to what is happening in the Brisbane tower. I can tell honourable members that a heck of a lot can be learned about the operation of the Civil Aviation Authority by monitoring some of those conversations.

As I have said, in a personal sense, I have got no vested interest in this. But the reality is that these aeroplanes do stray from their official flight paths. In terms of that area on the south side of Brisbane—through Balmoral Heights and Cannon Hill and down through Tingalpa to the Seven Hills area—people have a real problem. The government has duckshoved this for a number of years, and has denied that there is a problem there. My estimate is that we will probably see nothing whatsoever done about it.

I have mentioned Coolangatta, and there are other airports around Australia which have these problems. I hope some people are not going to get their hopes up too much when they read that this legislation is in play, because this legislation provides only for jet aircraft, yet there are many airports that receive incredible amounts of noise from non-jet aircraft. The people of Moorabbin and surrounding places are not going to get any benefit from this particular legislation.

One could look at Archerfield, in Brisbane. Any member on the south side of Brisbane will talk about the phone calls he gets—at 4 o'clock in the morning, at home—from the residents of Salisbury or Oxley because the propeller driven freighters are going over at 4 o'clock in the morning and blasting everybody out of their beds. Those people are not going to get any relief from this particular legislation, because we are only covering jet aircraft.

Like my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), I get a bit cynical about this, because the passengers who are going to be hit more than anybody else are the poor devils flying on the BAe146, one of the quietest aircraft in the skies. Are honourable members aware that we are so good that Australia is the only country in the world that has any curfew on the BAe146 whatsoever? Australia is the only country in the world that has any restrictions on this. The BAe146 happily flies around freight services during all hours of the day and night in Europe, with no restrictions whatsoever. But we come in here and we slam every passenger on the BAe146 $5.17 per head, on average. I really wonder.I know there are supposed to be provisions here to ensure that there is going to be no major profit made by the authorities from this particular operation. But I really wonder why that BAe146 crept in here.

In fact, I would have thought that they might have been given a bit more encouragement than, say, the Boeing 727, which is still operated by Ansett. When the honourable member for Watson and I started talking about aircraft noise in Sydney, the real argument, to a very great extent, has been about the fact that the 727 is still operating over some of those areas. It is a very rowdy aircraft.

The two aircraft that probably cause more concern than most—they certainly do on the south side of Brisbane—are the Fokker F28 and the Boeing 727, which are old aircraft. The F28, apparently, is going out of service. Ansett was suggesting that we were going to see the demise of the 727 from its fleet late last year. There are now suggestions that the 727 could be flying well into the next century. Unless they are hush-kitted, we are going to have some enormous problems there. But the fact that the BAe146 has got the big slam really makes me quite amused.

The real worry is that this particular legislation is not going to cover a number of other people around Australia who have some real difficulties in terms of aircraft noise. I would hope that the government would prove to be quite genuine in providing for the people of Sydney, who have got their own specific problems, and genuine in terms of the people who live in the flight path of the Coolangatta airport or on the south side of Brisbane. I hope the government will be genuine for the people at Archerfield, Moorabbin or Bankstown, and make sure that all those who are badly affected by aircraft noise do get some sort of compensation.

Most importantly, let us hope that there is some honesty, and that the officials who are responsible for these things do not try to duckshove some of the noise readings and some of the formulas that they use. Let us make sure they get out there amongst the real people who are experiencing these noises. Let us make sure they put their monitoring services underneath the actual flight paths instead of the theoretical flight paths, and let us try to get some justice for the great number of people who are being very deeply affected by aircraft noise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Mrs M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 is for an act to impose a levy on the landing of jet aircraft at certain airports. At the moment, this policy is directed at Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport. The purpose of this levy is to attempt to introduce some financially based discipline on the use of Sydney Kingsford Smith airport.

PARA.TAB: Currently, the residents of the inner city and certain northern suburbs of Sydney are sorely punished by the operations of this airport. The opening of the third runway has not proved to be an improvement. The situation is now worse and residents of my electorate and those of Sydney, Grayndler and Bennelong demand that this parliament do something definite to ameliorate their suffering. Hopefully, this levy will go some way towards controlling the noise and take-off pattern of jet aircraft into and out of KSA.

There are two bills to deal with on this matter—the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995—and I will consider these together. In connection with these bills, I would also like to comment on the woeful situation that has brought about the requirement for this levy. Given the financial commitment, both public and private, and the current standards of the infrastructure at Sydney airport, it is patently obvious that this facility will remain in operation for many years to come. I think that the calls to close Sydney airport at this stage are wide of the mark. It is also clear, given the above premise, that aircraft operations will affect a substantial number of Sydney residents and these residents require, on health and public amenity grounds, the insulation of premises, reduction of engine noise and rigorous control of the flight paths.

In reducing the rate of growth at Sydney airport, the government has no option but to press ahead with a second airport at Sydney West. Our tourism industry cannot be curtailed. It is our biggest export earner and the Sydney Olympics is staring us in the face. Knowing this, the government has committed substantial funds to the new airport. The May 1995 federal budget contained a commitment to provide $610 million additional funding for the accelerated development of Sydney West airport by 1999. This budget allocation means a total funding commitment by the government of $762 million for the site development and infrastructure.

This is excellent news but, again, I emphasise that, as of today, no concrete has been poured so, although Sydney West airport will provide some solace in the years ahead to my constituents, what about the immediate future of the next four years? As for the suffering of residents due to the current operation of Sydney airport, I do acknowledge the decision of the federal government to approve $183.4 million over the next 10 years aimed at reducing the impact of aircraft noise on residents living around Sydney airport. This program was announced as costing $183.4 million in November 1994, as estimated by the FAC consultants. Following the extension of the coverage of the program and more detailed costings, the estimated costs have now increased by $76.6 million to $260 million. The major reasons for the increase in these costs estimated by the FAC consultants are: additional buildings identified for treatment within the previously announced categories and assistant areas; outcome of more detailed assessment of work required, particularly for air-conditioning, structural reinforcement and electrical work in schools and colleges; an upward movement in external noise levels to more clearly reflect the actual measured aircraft noise and resultant upwards adjustment in the level of sound treatment required; cost estimates for preliminary design documentation; and the project management not included in the earlier estimates.

The government announced the immediate commencement of the schools installation program with completion targeted for the end of the first term of this year but the state, Catholic and other school administrations have subsequently expressed a preference for a staged approach to noise treatment so that the schools experience minimum disruption to educational activities. The eligible schools in my electorate of Lowe are Drummoyne public school and St Marks Catholic school in Drummoyne. Child-care facilities will also eventually be eligible. These will include Drummoyne Occasional Child Care Centre, College Street Child Care Centre, Drummoyne municipal preschool and Drummoyne Baptist preschool. The following churches and other places of worship will also eventually be eligible: Drummoyne Baptist Church, Drummoyne Presbyterian Church, St Marks Catholic Church and Drummoyne Uniting Church.

The noise amelioration measures are useful and timely and I think that much attention must be given to this question of noise as it is a major health question. The bills before us today are stated to be for the purpose of financing this noise amelioration. The financial impact statement contained in the general outline of the bills says:

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of levy to be prescribed under the legislation will be designed to recover the costs associated with noise amelioration works currently under way in Sydney, with a target collection rate of $32.2 million in the 1995/96 financial year.
I hope that this is true. My electors and the residents of Sydney would be very disappointed and angry if moneys raised by these bills were to disappear into consolidated revenue.

PARA.TAB: I am not very happy to have to call into question the honesty of public officials. However, the saga of this airport and the third runway and all the associated matters have brought about a situation where a lot of Sydney residents simply do not believe the word of any official associated with this matter. This is a sad situation, but the facts of the matter do give grounds for deep suspicion. We must ensure that these bills do not end up increasing the duplicity surrounding this matter.

Before I go on speaking on the various clauses of the bill, I want to put on the record the serious health and social issues associated with noise. Aircraft noise above a certain level is a public health risk and, since the opening of the third runway, the New South Wales health department has been collecting data on the use of medical resources by residents affected by the aircraft noise. More than 70,000 people in Sydney now live within the high noise contour area. Overseas studies have conclusively shown that aircraft noise is a serious cause of illness and the noise raises the stress level for the very young and the very old. Medical investigations in Sydney show that areas affected by high aircraft noise have a higher degree of arteriosclerosis, nephritis and nephrosis, and heart disease. Local general practitioners report a serious rise in insomnia, anxiety, high blood pressure and nerve ailments.

The government's preferred option in dealing with this problem is embodied in these bills. Frankly, I doubt whether fines will work effectively. I strongly suspect that the new community consultative committee, established by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and chaired by Joe Riordan, will have to work very hard to monitor these prosecutions carefully, as well as the respective fines.

These bills levy a payment on some jet aircraft landing at some prescribed airports. At the moment, it covers Sydney airport, but it is to be expanded with ministerial approval. The levy will represent approximately $3.40 per passenger in a jet aircraft at Sydney airport and it is intended that the levy rate will be adjusted in line with consumer price index movements. The aim will be to recover the costs associated with the program over a period of not more than 10 years.

Clauses 5 and 6 detail the method of calculation of the levy and stipulate that the levy shall be the same at all airports where a levy is charged. Because of the complexities of aircraft ownership—leaseholds, rentings, borrowings and all the other legal words surrounding possession and use—clause 4 of the levy collection bill boasts that it has a comprehensive definition of operator and thus identifies the person who must pay the levy.

Clause 6 of part 2 tells us about identifying those airports that qualify for the levy. Subclause (6) identifies the concept of ANEF. The ANEF system of noise measurement appears to be a questionable and easily manipulated one. It operates only in Australia and has been used extensively by the Civil Aviation Authority over the years. The CAA is now to be abolished by the government.

Clause 8 in part 3 leaves the question of actually paying the levy to be settled by regulation. I would suggest that the government not delay in issuing these regulations. I know that bureaucracy is large and deliberate and that it is invariably bad to rush things. However, I would again urge the bureaucracy and the ministry to be aware that the general public in Sydney is extremely distrustful of government in this area of civil aviation. This is a bad situation and my desire is to see the government adopt policies and regulations that actually address the aviation problems and help restore that level of trust and confidence that must exist between the people and their government.

Part 4 of the levy collection bill deals with the power to gather information relevant to collecting the levy. This legislation is needed; I hope that it works. I have pointed out a few problems and perhaps I am wrong, but the bottom line is that swift and sure remedial action is needed to solve the noise problem at Sydney Kingsford Smith airport and to rapidly advance the construction of Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek.
Motion (by Mr Snowdon) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.
Consideration resumed from 11 May.
Motion (by Mr Snowdon) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:
